column1: #Text=This repository contains the code developed for the Master Thesis in Digital Humanities and Digital Knwoledge at the University of Bologna, under the supervision of Prof.
#Text=Aldo Gangemi and the supervision of Prof.
#Text=Afterwards, the work was expanded and revised for the following publication:
#Text=The HaMSE Ontology: Using Semantic Technologies to support Music Representation Interoperability and Musicological Analysis.
#Text=More specifically, the repository three main types of resources:
#Text=* the code used to extract different features from music content [src folder](#src).
#Text=* the [HaMSE ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/andreamust/HaMSE_Ontology/master/schema), which proposes to represent these features

#Text=* a small [Knowledge Base](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/andreamust/HaMSE_Ontology/master/data), containing an example of data extracted with the algorithms aforementioned and modelled using the HaMSE Ontology.
#Text=The data extraction algorithms are divided into five main categories, aiming at extracting five different types of musical features.
#Text=The image below summarises these categories and the features belonging to each of them:
#Text=The Audio-to-score Alignment serves for interconnecting different symbolic music representation systems with the audio representation.
#Text=For this task, we used a classic approach based on Dynamic Time Warping (DTW).
#Text=In particular, we have used the DTW algorithm provided by the [Librosa](https://github.com/librosa/librosa).
#Text=More specifically, the symbolic notation has been converted to audio signal using the [Midi2audio library](https://github.com/bzamecnik/midi2audio).
#Text=The two signals have been then aligned using the DTW algorithm.
#Text=This is an example of the alignment between two tracks:
#Text=
#Text=The chosen approach is based on features extraction from raw audio, utilising machine learning techniques.
#Text=In particular, the approach I followed is based on deep neural networks.

#Text=The idea behind the extraction of psychoacoustic and emotional features is to train a deep neural network using a dataset labelled with this kind of features, and then make predictions on unseen data.
#Text=This approach will allow us to understand the emotion aroused by the piece (or a part of a piece) we are analysing.
#Text=The dataset chosen for this task is the 4Q audio emotion dataset30 provided by the Centre for Informatics and Systems on the University of Coimbra (Panda, Malheiro and Paiva 2018).
#Text=The dataset is made up of 900 audio-clips of 30 seconds length, divided into four different groups.
#Text=These groups are defined according to the four quadrants of Russell’s model.
#Text=Russell in 1980 introduced a Circumplex Model of Affect (Russell 1980) that aimed at spatially representing interrelations between affective dimensions.
#Text=The best performance in training the model (77.2% in accuracy) were obtained using a Convolutional Recurrent Network, which layers were organised as follows:
#Text=Extracting melodic features means horizontally investigating the music data, analysing what is functional to the melody.
#Text=For these experiments we decided to extract different types of melodic patterns, using a relatively trivial approach based on n-grams.
#Text=To support the scanning of symbolic representations we reused [music21](https://github.com/cuthbertLab/music21) and [The VIS framework](https://github.com/ELVIS-Project/vis-framework).
#Text=The implemented algorithm allows the extraction of different types of melodic patterns, including:
#Text=All these types can be extracted either considering rests or not.
#Text=For harmonic features, we implemented an algorithm to extract several harmonic features, including:
#Text=* the dissonances present in the song
#Text=* the chords that are formed in polyphonic compositions
#Text=* the recurrent harmonic sequences, using a mirror approach to that proposed in the previous section.

#Text=For the structural features of the song, i.e. the structure and sections that make up the song, we reused the [MSAF library](https://pythonhosted.org/msaf/tutorial.html), using it directly on the audio signal.
#Text=Starting from the lack of ontologies that deal with musicological research in an extensive way, we propose a novel ontological model.
#Text=This new model merges and harmonizes two or more different and non-interoperable music representations (e.g. audio data and scores), either symbolic or non-symbolic.
#Text=This approach has multiple advantages: by connecting different MSRs, it will be possible to exploit all the characteristics that such representations can provide.
#Text=Secondly, this novel representation attempts to solve some of the problems that affect contemporary musicology.
#Text=The documentation of the ontology, together with other more specific information is hosted on [The HaMSE Project Website](https://andreapoltronieri.org/HaMSE_project/).
#Text=The URI of this ontology is the following: `https://github.com/andreamust/HaMSE_Ontology/schema`
#Text=We created a small knowledge base in order to test the ontology.
#Text=The knowledge base was populated with data from a Bach’s chorale, namely the sixth movement of the church cantata Wie schön leuchtet der Morgenstern.
#Text=The piece is catalogued under the index BWV1.
#Text=The sixth and last movement is the chorale entitled *"Wie bin ich doch so herzlich froh"*.
#Text=          title     = {The HaMSE Ontology: Using Semantic Technologies to support Music Representation
#Text=A more advanced version of this work can be found in:
#Text=          booktitle={Proceedings of the 12th Workshop on Ontology Design and Patterns (WOP 2021), Online, October 24, 2021.},
